items.message:
The flood alert has been issued for the North Sea Coast at Bridlington. We are expecting overtopping, wave and spray between 5:30pm and 11pm on Sunday 27th March. The area at risk is Bridlington South Pier.
We will continue to monitor the situation.

This message contains gauge information for Sedgeberrow and Hinton.

This message will be updated by 4 pm to day or if the situation changes.

At 8 am today;

the level at the Sedgeberrow Gauge was 1.89 metres and rising. A peak level of between 2.0 and 2.1 metres is expected to occur this morning.

the level at the Hinton Gauge was 2.30 metres and rising. A peak level of between 2.5 and 2.8 metres is expected to occur this afternoon.

items.description: Rivers in the Forest of Dean
items.message:
This message contains gauge information for Parkend and Lydney.

This message will be updated by 4 pm today or if the situation changes.

At 8:30 am today;

the level at the Parkend Gauge was 0.70 metres and steady, a peak level is occurring now this morning.

the level at the Lydney Gauge was 0.61 metres and rising. A peak level of between 0.7 and 0.9 metres is expected to occur this morning.

items.description: River Leen and Day Brook in Nottinghamshire
items.message: As Storm Katie moves across the country during the early hours of Monday, frontal rain is forecast bringing heavy rainfall at times. Flooding is possible at areas north of Moor Bridge at Bulwell, Southwark Street meander and the Day Brook Confluence in Basford. Valley Road Playing Fields and low lying land along the Day Brook may also be affected. The current best estimate forecast is for widespread 15 to 20 mm of rain across the area, with higher totals possible in some locations. River levels are expected to respond to the overnight rainfall throughout Monday. We are continuing to monitor the situation with operational staff out checking watercourses and clearing debris screens. For up to date information on river levels in your area go to the river and sea levels section on the .GOV.UK website.

As Storm Katie moves across the country during the early hours of Monday frontal rain is forecast, bringing heavy rainfall at times. Flooding is possible at Mansfield, The Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton. The current best estimate forecast is for widespread 15 to 20 mm of rain across the area, with higher totals possible in some locations. River levels are expected to respond to the overnight rainfall throughout Monday. We are continuing to monitor the situation with operational staff out checking watercourses and clearing debris screens. Flooding is possible from some tributaries of the River Trent in Nottinghamshire. These include the River Greet, Potwell Dyke, Carr Dyke, Dover Beck, Cocker Beck, Thurgaton Beck, Fairham Brook and others. The current best estimate forecast is for widespread 15 to 20 mm of rain across the area, with higher totals possible in some locations. Large surges and 5m waves will co-inside with high tide at 02:21. There is the potential of over-topping due to the wave heights at Yarmouth and Ryde, though impacts will be minor. The time and date of high water is 02:21 on Monday 28/03/2016. The total forecast high water is 2.11 metres above ordnance datum, which is the equivalent of 4.7  metres above chart datum. The local wind strength is Force  9 in a Southerly direction.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued as a precaution on the basis of heavy rain forecast for overnight and into Monday morning.  Widespread 20 mm of rain is forecast with higher totals possible locally.  This will cause river levels to rise in the early hours of Monday morning.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: The current level at the Lilbourne river gauge is 0.33 metres.   River levels are rising slowly on the Upper Avon, River Swift and Clay Coton Brook  with flooding possible today. River levels are expected to peak between 1.0 and 1.3 metres at the Lilbourne gauge.  Over the past 12 hours there has been 11 millimetres of rain. Further rainfall is  forecast over the next 12 hours with totals of around 10 millimetres expected.

This Flood Alert has been issued as a precaution on the basis of heavy rain forecast for overnight and into Monday morning.  Widespread 20 mm of rain is forecast with higher totals possible locally.  This will cause river levels to rise in the early hours of Monday morning.

This Flood Alert has been issued as a precaution on the basis of heavy rain forecast for overnight and into Monday morning.  Widespread 20 mm of rain is forecast with higher totals possible locally .  This will cause river levels to rise in the early hours of Monday morning.

This Flood Alert has been issued as a precaution on the basis of heavy rain forecast for overnight and into Monday morning.  Widespread 20 mm of rain is forecast with higher totals possible locally.  This will cause river levels to rise in the early hours of Monday morning.

The current level at the Leek river gauge is 0.5 metres.   River levels are rising quickly with flooding possible today.  Over the past 12 hours there has been 30 millimetres of rain. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours with rainfall totals reducing this morning. For up to date information on river levels, go to the Environment and Countryside section of the GOV.UK official website.

items.message:
This message contains gauge information for Rea Brook.

This message will be updated by 4 pm today or if the situation changes.

At 7 am today;

the level at the Rea Brook, Hookagate Gauge was 1.01 metres and rising. A peak level of between 0.9 and 1.5 metres is expected to occur this morning.

Water levels in the River Wey, Preston Brook and River Jordan are expected to rise and could exceed bankful conditions.

Between 5-10mm of rainfall has already fallen in localised heavy showers during the day.  Up to additional 20mm of rainfall is forecast over night from Sunday evening to Monday early morning.  There is a low chance of upto 30mm in localised areas.

Water levels in the Rivers in West Dorset including the Rivers Lim, Winniford, Char, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride are expected to rise and are forecast to exceed bankful conditions.

Between 5-10mm of rainfall has already fallen in localised heavy showers during the day.  Up to additional 20mm of rainfall is forecast over night from Sunday evening to Monday early morning.  There is a low chance of upto 30mm in localised areas.

items.description: Rivers on the Isle of Sheppey
items.message: This Flood Alert is being issued in anticipation of ‘Storm Katie’ which is forecast to bring heavy showers overnight and into Easter Monday morning. Rainfall totals of up to 35 mm are possible which could cause the rivers to react quickly and lead to flooding of low-lying land. The Warden Bay drain is particularly responsive to heavy rainfall. River levels are likely to remain high due to tide locking from high tides.  Flooding of properties is not currently expected but we will be monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message on Easter Monday morning.

As Storm Katie moves across the country during the early hours of Monday, frontal rain is forecast bringing heavy rainfall at times. Flooding of low-lying agricultural land and roads is possible from the Black Brook and the Shepshed to Hathern Road may be affected. Similar issues may be experienced around other watercourses in Loughborough, including the Grace Dieu Brook, Burleigh Brook, Wood Brook and Grammar School Brook. The current best estimate forecast is for widespread 15 to 20 mm of rain across the area, with higher totals possible in some locations. River levels are expected to respond to the overnight rainfall throughout Monday. We are continuing to monitor the situation with operational staff out checking watercourses and clearing debris screens. For up to date information on river levels in your area go to the river and sea levels section on the .GOV.UK website.

As Storm Katie moves across the country during the early hours of Monday, frontal rain is forecast bringing heavy rainfall at times. The current best estimate forecast is for widespread 15 to 20 mm of rain across the area, with higher totals possible in some locations. River levels are expected to respond to the overnight rainfall throughout Monday. items.message: Very windy and wet conditions are expected to arrive late on Sunday evening and continue until mid-morning on Monday. The current forecast is for widespread rainfall totals of 20mm, with up to 30-40mm locally, especially over higher ground. Flooding to low-lying land and roads is expected from midnight on Sunday and is likely to remain throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
This alert has been issued due to the rain associated with Storm Katie which is due to pass into Hertfordshire from 9pm Easter Sunday until Monday morning. 

The nature of this weather system means that whilst 15-20mm of rain can be expected widely, other areas may have high localised totals and some may see less.  

Current forecasts suggest that the river Colne in the Colney Heath and London Colney area will react to this rain, coming close to if not out of its banks during the early hours of Easter Monday. Localised surface water flooding is also likely.

We will continue to monitor the situation and update these Flood Alerts Monday morning or earlier if required.

This alert has been issued due to the rain associated with Storm Katie which is due to pass into the London area from 9pm Easter Sunday until Monday morning. 

The nature of this weather system means that whilst 15-20mm of rain can be expected widely, other areas may have high localised totals and some may see less.  

Current forecasts suggest that the river Crane in the Cranford park area will react to this rain, coming close to if not out of its banks during the early hours of Easter Monday. Localised surface water flooding is also likely.

We will continue to monitor the situation and update these Flood Alerts Monday morning or earlier if required.

items.message: This flood alert is based on a forecast. Very wet and windy conditions are expected to arrive late this evening and continue until mid-morning tomorrow. With some uncertainty around where the heaviest rain will fall, there is potential for minor river flooding to occur between 10pm tonight and 10am tomorrow morning. We will continue to monitor the situation but are not expecting to issue any flood warnings.

items.description: Sor Brook and The Bloxham Brook and their tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Sor, Bloxham Brook, Hornton Stream

items.message:
The River and Flooding forecast is as follows:  Property flooding is not currently expected. However, levels on the Sor and Bloxham Brooks remain high, especially in the Bloxham area. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue. Levels are forecast to stabilise over the next 24 hours. 
The weather prospects are: A heavy band of rain will clear by midday on Monday, there will be scattered showers throughout the afternoon. Tuesday will be showery in the morning, with more persistent rain in the afternoon.

items.message: This flood alert is based on a forecast. Very wet and windy conditions are expected to arrive late this evening and continue through tomorrow morning. With some uncertainty around where the heaviest rain will fall, there is potential for minor river flooding to occur between midnight tonight and midday tomorrow.

This is a pre-emptive alert ahead of tonight's rainfall from Storm Katie. River levels have risen as a result of heavy showers through the weekend and remain high.  With heavy rain forecast overnight it is likely that river levels will rise further in the early hours of Monday morning resulting in flooding to low lying land and roads.  Flooding of properties are not expected.  Strong winds may also result in some localised obstructions to river flow caused by falling branches.  We continue to monitor the situation closely and will update this message tomorrow morning or earlier as required.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
items.message: The current level at the Swindon river gauge is 1.96 metres.   River levels are rising slowly on the  with flooding possible  River levels are expected to peak between 2.5 and 2.8 metres   Over the past 12 hours there has been 28 millimetres of rain. Further rainfall is  forecast over the next 12 hours with totals of around 15 millimetres expected.

River levels in the Cuckmere have risen today due to the rainfall over the last 24 hours. Although levels are dropping in most areas, heavy overnight rain is forecast and we are likely to see levels rise further with the potential of flooding to low lying land and some rural roads. This may include areas such as Alfriston Road and areas near Horsebridge and Hellingly. We will continue to monitor the situation overnight and into tomorrow once the rain falls and update this message as necessary.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
The River and Flooding forecast is as follows: Property flooding is not currently expected. However, levels on the River Blackwater in the Camberley area have been rising steadily throughout the day in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise tonight and flooding of low lying land and roads is expected early tomorrow morning.
The weather prospects are further heavy rain showers throught the night and into Monday

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle

items.message:
Up to 20 mm of rainfall is forecast overnight this evening and into the early hours of tomorrow morning. Further heavy thundery showers are expected throughout Monday possibly bringing a further 15 mm of rain to the area.
River levels on the River Yeo at Sherborne Lake, River Wriggle at Chetnole, River Cam at Weston Bampfylde, and the Stoford and Barwick Streams at Stoford are all expected to rise in response to this rainfall.

items.description: Plenty, Swalecliffe and West Brooks Area

floodArea.riverOrSea: Plenty Brook, Swalecliffe Brook,  West Brook

items.message: This is a pre-emptive alert ahead of tonight's rainfall from Storm Katie. River levels have risen as a result of heavy showers through the weekend and remain high.  With heavy rain forecast overnight it is likely that river levels will rise further in the early hours of Monday morning resulting in flooding to low lying land and roads.  Flooding of properties are not expected.  High tide is expected around 04:00 BST and could combine with river flow to increase levels in the brooks.  Strong winds may also result in some localised obstructions to river flow caused by falling branches.  We continue to monitor the situation closely and will update this message tomorrow morning or earlier as required.

Up to 20 mm of rainfall is forecast overnight this evening and into the early hours of tomorrow morning. Further heavy thundery showers are expected throughout Monday possibly bringing a further 15 mm of rain to the area.
River levels on the River Isle at Donyatt, River Isle at Ashford Mill, River Parrett at Chiselborough and River Parrett at Gawbridge are all expected to rise in response to the forecast rainfall.

items.message:
Up to 20 mm of rainfall is forecast overnight this evening and into the early hours of tomorrow morning. Further heavy thundery showers are expected throughout Monday possibly bringing a further 15 mm of rain to the area.
River levels across the West Somerset catchment are all expected to react to the forecast rainfall.

Strong onshore winds will cause tides to rise further.
The time and date of the forecast high water is 10:15 on 28/03/2016. The forecast tide level is 5.17 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 7  West north westerly. 

Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Chew, Chew Stoke Stream, Winford Brook

items.message:
Overnight rainfall associated with storm Katie has produced totals of up to 25 mm across the catchment. Blustery showers are expected to continue throughout the day producing up to a further 5 mm of rainfall.
River levels on the Chew Stoke Stream at Chew Stoke and Winford Brook at Chew Magna  peaked at 03:00 am on 28/03/2016 and are falling. River levels on the  River Chew at Compton Dando peaked at 06:00 am on 28/03/2016 and are falling.

Overnight rainfall associated with storm Katie has produced totals of up to 25 mm across the catchment. Blustery showers are expected to continue throughout the day producing up to a further 5 mm of rainfall.
 River levels on the Tetbury Avon at Brokenborough, Sherston Avon at Fosseway are stable. River levels on the  River Avon at Great Somerford and Dauntsey Brook at Dauntsey are rising.

We have seen heavy rainfall over the course of the evening on the Blackburn Brook catchment which has caused river levels to slowly rise. We expect to see further rain affecting the catchment until around midday today when the wet weather begins to clear further eastwards. As a result, we expect levels to rise further which may lead to some surface water flooding. We do not currently expect any flooding to property but we will continue to monitor the situation closely and will provide you with any updates throughout the morning. 

River levels can be viewed on our website at https://flood-warning-information.service.gov.uk/riverlevels?location=blackburn+brook

The forecast tide level is high.  The tide may affect the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the pond.  Large waves may also be seen along the coast as Storm Katie  brings 60 to 70 miles per hour winds offshore. The storm will ease by mid morning.  The time and date of high water is 02:03 on Monday 28/03/2016. The total forecast high water is 2.18 metres above ordnance datum, which is the equivalent of 4.18 metres above chart datum. The local wind strength is Force 9 in a Southerly direction.

The forecast tide level is high and all tidal defence gates should be closed. At Town Quay Lymington, near the Ship Inn pub, water may leak through the defence gates and flood the parking areas.  Large waves may also be seen on top of the high tide as Storm Katie  brings 60 to 70 miles per hour winds offshore. The storm will ease by mid morning.  The time and date of high water is 02:04 on Monday 28/03/2016. The total forecast high water is 1.76 metres above ordnance datum, which is the equivalent of 3.72 metres above chart datum. The local wind strength is Force 9 in a Southerly direction.

Storm Katie is bringing with it high winds and large waves overnight tonight. The high winds are coinciding with the high tide and waves of up to 5 metres may be seen on top of the high tide. The waves rather than the tide level may lead to over-topping and spray in some place leading to minor flooding impacts. The storm will ease by mid morning. Water will be high around South Street, Emsworth and Queen Street near the Slipper Pond.  The Ship Inn car park at Langstone may flood and water will be high at the bottom of Langstone high street The time and date of high water is 02:41 on Monday 28/03/2016. The total forecast high water is 2.38 metres above ordnance datum, which is the equivalent of 5.11 metres above chart datum. The local wind strength is Force  9 in a Southerly direction.

The following Flood Alerts will remain in force for two hours following the times of high tide.

The time and date of the forecast high waters for which this Flood Alert is in force are : 01:45 am (Local time) on 28/03/2016 ( 00:45 am GMT) and 05:00 am (Local time) on 28/03/2016 ( 04:00 am GMT).

The forecast wind direction are South and South South West

The forecast wind strengths are Force 9  and Force 8

items.message: Heavy rain experienced this evening has caused river levels to rise quickly. The rainfall is expect to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to low-lying land and roads is expected from midnight on Sunday and is likely to remain throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes.

River levels in the River Plym are rising quickly in response to intense rainfall over the past few hours. Levels are expected to rise further as further intense showers are forecast to occur overnight
Rivers are rising in response to this evening's rain with more forecast into the early hours of this morning. Some minor river flooding is expected.

River levels in the River Yealm are rising quickly in response to intense rainfall over the past few hours. Levels are expected to rise further as another band of intense showers are forecast to occur into the early hours of this morning.

River levels in the River Lynher are rising quickly in response to intense rainfall over the past few hours. Levels are expected to rise further as another band of intense showers are forecast to occur into the early hours of this morning.

The forecast wind strength is Force 8

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message:
Rain is expected to continue until about 6 am on Monday morning before clearing the area. Further showers, thundery at times, will follow throughout the day.
River levels on the River Tone at Greenham, River Tone at Bishops Hull, River Tone at Taunton, Hillfarrance Brook at Milverton and Halsewater Stream at Halsewater are all rising in response to the recent rainfall.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Creedy, Yeo (Creedy), Lapford Yeo, Little Dart

items.message: The heavy rain experienced overnight has caused river levels to rise. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to low-lying land and roads is expected. River levels will remain high and out of banks throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes.

In the last 6 hours approximately 15mm of rain has fallen over an already saturated catchment. High tide is coinciding with the heavy rainfall along with high winds of Storm Katie. This is all combining to  raise water levels in the river and to keep them high for at least the next couple of hours. There is a heavy rainfall alert in force for until midday on March 28. While the majority of the widespread rain has passed through there is still the chance of heavy isolated showers. There is the potential for properties along Woodland Road to be affected due to the nature of the river channel in this location. 

This  Flood Alert will be updated at 1600 on Monday 28 March.

In the last 6 hours approximately 15mm of rain has fallen over an already saturated catchment. High tide is coinciding with the heavy rainfall along with high winds of Storm Katie. This is all combining to  raise water levels in the river and to keep them high for at least the next couple of hours. There is a heavy rainfall alert in force for until midday on March 28. While the majority of the widespread rain has passed through there is still the chance of heavy isolated showers and if these hit the Gurnard catchment they may prolong the tide locking. 

This  Flood Alert will be updated at 1600 on Monday 28 March.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett, Lower Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, River Cary, River Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
The current band of rain will clear the area by about 6:00 am. Further scattered showers, thundery at times, are expected throughout the day. River levels on the Cannington Brook at Cannington, River Yeo at Pen Mill, River Yeo at Ilchester and River Parrett at Langport Westover are all rising in response to rainfall. The drain level at Langport Westover pumping station is 5.49 m and is stable

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 6.01 m and is rising. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road when this level exceeds 7.30 m and the Muchelney to Thorney road when this level exceeds 7.93 m.

Heavy rain has fallen in the last 6 hours over an already saturated catchment. The rain in combination with high tide has  raised water levels in the brook at its downstream end. High tide as passed but tide levels have not fallen enough to let the water drain from the river yet so the brook remains tide locked  for at least the next couple of hours. There is a heavy rainfall alert in force for until midday on March 28 but the majority of the widespread rain has passed through. There is still the chance of heavy isolated showers and if these hit the catchment they may prolong the tide locking. 

This  Flood Warning will be updated at 1600 on Monday 28 March.
River levels in the River Seaton are rising quickly due to the intense rainfall over the past few hours. River levels could continue to rise in response to this rain throughout the morning.

Heavy overnight rain has led water levels in the Rother to rise. Some 25mm has fallen over the catchment in the past 12 hours so we expect levels will continue to rise through Monday daytime in the whole area. We do not expect to see any further significant rainfall into the afternoon. There is the potential of localised surface water flooding throughout the catchment and care should be taken when travelling. We will review this message by 19:00 on the 28/3/2016

Heavy overnight rain has led water levels in the Ouse to rise. Currently levels are high around the Lindfield Bridge area. We expect levels will continue to rise in other areas through Monday daytime, especially around Anchor gates and Barcombe Mills.  We do not expect to see any further significant rainfall into the afternoon. There is the potential of localised surface water flooding throughout the catchment and care should be taken when travelling. We will review this message by 19:00 on the 28/3/2016

items.message: We have received 20mm of rain in the River Mole in the last 12 hours causing the river to respond. The river is expected to peak at Kinnersley this afternoon and further downstream on Monday evening. Flooding of low lying land is expected. We do not expect any property flooding from the rivers at this time. The forecast for the next few days shows a continuation of showers. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this flood alert throughout the day.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.39 m and is rising by approximately 6 mm per hour. The current rate of rise is slowing.
Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 4.72 m and is rising by approximately 5 mm per hour.  
Flooding will affect Cuts Road if this level exceeds 5.75 m and New Road in Currymoor if this level exceeds 6.18 m. Water will spill over Athelney spillway, across the A361 and into Saltmoor and Northmoor if this level exceeds 7.10 m.
The drain level at Northmoor pumping station is 3.0 m and is stable.There is a risk of flooding to property and roads in Northmoor if this level exceeds 4.20 m.Pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations.The rain has generally passed out of the area. There is a chance of an isolated heavy shower throughout the day on Monday.

items.description: North Sea Coast at Bridlington - Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion
River Yarty from Yarcombe to Axminster
items.message: Heavy rain experienced this evening has caused river levels to rise quickly. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to property close to the river is expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes.

items.description: River Walkham from Huckworthy to Bedford Bridge
items.message: River levels are rising rapidly in response to heavy rain passing over Cornwall and Devon this evening, with more rain forecast over the next few hours.

items.description: River Yealm at Yealmbridge and Yealmpton
items.message: River levels in the River Yealm are rising quickly in response to intense rainfall over the past few hours. Levels are expected to rise further as further intense showers are forecast to occur overnight.

items.description: River Wriggle at Chetnole, Mill Lane and Deep Ford Lane areas
items.message: Rainfall is expected to continue through until about 6 am on Monday morning before clearing to leave a spell of heavy thundery showers. River levels on the River Wriggle at Chetnole are rising.

The following Flood Warning will remain in force for two hours following the time of high tide.

Flooding may already be affecting properties, low lying areas and roads.

The time and date of the forecast high water for which this Flood Warning is in force is: 01:30 am (Local time) on 28/03/2016 ( 00:30 am GMT).

The forecast wind direction is South South West

The forecast wind strength is Force 8

Water levels in the upper Frome at Maiden Newton are rising and expected to peak over night.

The rainfall is forecast to continue until about 05:00 am (local time) on 28/03/2016 with upto a further 10 mm expected.

items.description: River Axe (Upper) from Winsham to Axminster, including Chard Junction and Weycroft
items.message: The heavy rain experienced Sunday evening and overnight has caused river levels to rise. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to property close to the river is expected early Monday morning. River levels will remain high and out of banks throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes

items.description: River Clyst from Broadclyst to Clyst St. Mary
items.message: The heavy rain experienced Sunday evening and overnight has caused river levels to rise. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to property close to the river is expected early Monday morning. River levels will remain high and out of banks throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes.

items.description: River Otter (Lower) from Salston to Budleigh Salterton
items.message: River levels are continuing to rise following the heavy rainfall experienced overnight. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to property close to the river is expected. The River Otter is expected to reach its highest level in the next 3-4 hours. River levels are likely to remain high and out of banks throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes

items.description: River Isle from Chard Reservoir to Hambridge
items.message:
Over 20 mm of rain has fallen in the area in the last 6 hours. Rain is expected to continue until about 6:00 am on Monday morning. Further showers, thundery at times, will follow throughout the day.
River levels on the River Isle at Donyatt and River Isle at Ashford Mill are rising.

items.description: River Culm (Upper) from Hemyock to Cullompton
items.message: River levels are continuing to rise following the heavy rainfall experienced overnight. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to property close to the river is possible early Monday morning. The River Culm is expected to reach its highest level at Culmstock in the next 3 to 4 hours. River levels are likely to remain high and out of banks throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester
items.message:
Water levels in the upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester are rising and expected to peak at Dorchester this morning

The rainfall is forecast to continue until about 07:00 am (local time) on 28/03/2016 with between 5 and 10mm of rainfall expected.

items.description: River Dart from Buckfastleigh to Totnes, including Staverton
items.message: River levels are continuing to rise following the heavy rainfall experienced overnight. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to property close to the river is possible early Monday morning. The River Dart is expected to reach its highest level at Austins Bridge in the next hour. River levels are likely to remain high and out of banks throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes.

items.description: River Parrett (upper) from South Perrott to Thorney
items.message: 20 mm of rainfall has fallen in the area in the last 6 hours. Rainfall is expected to clear the southwest early on Monday morning. This will be followed by scattered showers, thundery at times. River levels on the River Parrett at Chiselborough and River Parrett at Gawbridge are rising.

Heavy rain has fallen in the last 6 hours over an already saturated catchment. The rain in combination with high tide has  raised water levels in the river. High tide has passed but tide levels have not fallen enough to let the water drain from the river. The river’s water levels are tide locked  for at least the next couple of hours. There is a heavy rainfall alert in force for until midday on March 28. While the majority of the widespread rain has passed through there is still the chance of heavy isolated showers and if these hit the Gurnard catchment they may prolong the tide locking. Properties are at risk of flooding on Marsh Road.

This  Flood Warning will be updated at 1600 on Monday 28 March.

items.description: River Axe (Lower) from Axminster to Axmouth
items.message: River levels are continuing to rise following the heavy rainfall experienced overnight. The rainfall is expected to clear the area by mid-morning on Monday. Flooding to property close to the river is possible early Monday morning. The River Axe is expected to reach its highest level in the next 2 to 3 hours. River levels are likely to remain high and out of banks throughout Monday. We will continue to monitor the situation and update this message if the situation changes

The heavy rainfall associated with Storm Katie has caused river levels to rise considerably in the Lindfield area. We are still seeing the levels rise so recommend any property level protection measures are deployed as flooding to properties around Lindfield Bridge is now possible. As we go through Monday, we do expect to see levels start to drop as no further significant rainfall is forecast for the afternoon. We shall update this message by 13:00 on 28/3/2016

The current level at Swindon river level gauge is 2 metres. The river level is rising quickly, with flooding possible this morning. River levels are expected to peak between 2.5 and 2.8 metres. There has been 28 millimetres of rain over the past six hours.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next few hours with totals of around 15 millimetres expected.

items.description: River Nadder, Tisbury to West Harnham
items.message:
Water levels in the River Nadder from Tisbury to West Harnham are rising and expected to peak at West Harnham this morning.

No further significant rainfall is expected today

items.description: River Brue and Glastonbury Millstream from Lovington to Highbridge, low lying properties
items.message:
The rain has generally passed out of the southwest. Between 15 to 20 mm of rain has fallen in the overnight. The weather for Monday looks drier with the chance of isolated thundery showers.
River levels on the River Brue at Lovington and River Brue at Clyse Hole are rising but are forecast to peak in the next few hours.

items.description: River Yeo from Yeovil to Langport
items.message:
The rain has generally passed out of the area. Further isolated showers will follow throughout the day on Monday. Up to 20 mm of rain has fallen overnight and Rivers in East Somerset are reacting to this rainfall.

River levels on the River Yeo at Ilchester and River Yeo at Pen Mill are rising but are forecast to peak in the next few hours.

The current level at the Agnes Meadow Bridge river gauge is 1.4 metres. The river level is rising, with flooding possible this morning.  Over the past 12 hours there has been 35 millimetres of rain. Further rainfall is forecast this morning with further totals of around 10 millimetres expected.  Please remain vigilant.  For up to date information on river levels, go to the Environment and Countryside section of the GOV.UK official website.

items.description: Saredon Brook at Standeford near Coven
items.message: The current level at the Deepmore Farm river gauge is 1.27 metres. The river level is rising, with flooding possible this morning.  Over the past 12 hours there has been 30 millimetres of rain. Further rainfall is forecast this morning with totals of around 15 millimetres expected.  Please remain vigilant.  For up to date information on river levels, go to the Environment and Countryside section of the GOV.UK official website.

The Flood Warning for the Pocklington Beck at Pocklington has been issued. Levels are rising in response to recent rainfall. The current level at Pocklington is 0.45m and rising. We are expecting more rainfall and levels are expected to rise further.
We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Tean at Upper Tean, Lower Tean and Checkley
items.message: The current level at the Upper Tean river gauge is 1.4 metres. The river level is rising quickly, with flooding expected imminently.  Over the past 12 hour there has been 35 millimetres of rain. Further rainfall is  forecast over the next 6 hour with totals of around 17 milimetres expected. For up to date information on river levels,  go to the Environment and Countryside section of the GOV.UK official website.

items.description: River Stour at Mitford Bridge, Shipston on Stour and Tredington
items.message: This warning is issued based on forecast rainfall and expected river level response.  River levels are rising and are expected to continue to rise over the next few hours and could peak at around 3.20 metres at approximately midday today.  The current level at the Shipston river gauge is 2.78 metres. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  For up to date information on river levels, go to the Environment and Countryside section of the GOV.UK official website

items.description: River Dove at Hangingbridge and Church Mayfield
items.message: The current level at the Ashbourne river gauge is 1.5 metres. The river level is rising quickly, with flooding expected imminently.  Over the past 12 hour there has been up to 40 millimetres of rain. Further rainfall is  forecast over the next 6 hour with totals of around 17 millimetres expected. For up to date information on river levels,  go to the Environment and Countryside section of the GOV.UK official website.

We have seen heavy rainfall over the course of the evening on the River Rother catchment which has caused river levels at Chesterfield Tapton Bridge to rise. We expect to see further rain affecting the catchment until around midday today when the wet weather begins to clear further eastwards. As a result,  levels are expected to rise a little further which may lead to some surface water flooding and some instances of property flooding in this area although the intensity of the rainfall is currently dying down. We are continuing to monitor the situation very closely and will provide you with any updates throughout the morning
